results.title: Carmel: storyteller
results.brief_description: Carmel is a retired school teacher, wife, mother and grandmother. Her family’ s life dramatically changed when she was diagnosed with early onset memory loss. With her husband, she tells their story and looks positively in the face of an unknown future. Created as part of the ‘Memory’s Voice: Capturing Stories of Courage’ workshop, an ACMI Digital Storytelling Project in association with Alzheimer’s Australia Vic and in partnership with VicHealth.

results.title: Carlton + Godard = cinema [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Sunrise Picture Company and Nigel Buesst
results.brief_description:
A retrospective look at the film-making movement in Carlton during the 1960s/1970s, the filmmakers and the influences that inspired and motivated them. Includes an examination of the life and work of neo-realist Giorgio Mangiamele, and the French new wave styles of Brian Davies, Peter Carmody, Antony I. Ginnane, Peter Elliot, James Clayden, Nigel Buesst, David Minter. An assembly of extracts from several of the Carlton films are juxtaposed with pieces of Godard’s early films revealing much about a fascinating period of Melbourne filmmaking.
Features Antony I. Ginnane, Geoffrey Gardner, James Clayden, Bob Garlick, Giancarlo Giusti, Graeme Cutts. Narrated by Peter Fisher.

results.title: Carlito's way
results.creator_credit: Willi Baer, Michael S. Bregman, Brian De Palma, Universal Pictures and Martin Bregman
results.brief_description: Carlito Brigante (Al Pacino) is a Puerto Rican drug-lord who has been released from prison and is convinced he will begin a new life and remove himself from the violence of his criminal past. Filmed by thriller-master, Brian De Palma, “Carlito’s Way” is both a fiery and fast-paced gangster film and a powerful study of an individual attempting to come to terms with the failures of his past. Pacino is outstanding as Carlito, and so is Sean Penn, as a coke-snorting lawyer who is enamoured by Carlito’s past but ignorant of the dangers involved. This film is a more baroque and expansive treatment of the themes De Palma explored in his earlier “Scarface”. This is an adult gangster movie. The disco-tinged score (the movie is set in the late-seventies), is by Jellybean Benitez and features some great Latin and salsa disco music.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Willi Baer, Michael S. Bregman, Brian De Palma, Universal Pictures and Martin Bregman

results.title: Carla's song
results.creator_credit: Sally Hibbin, Bim Distribution, Channel 4, Film Four International, Parallax Pictures and Ken Loach
results.brief_description: George (Robert Carlyle) is a bus driver working in Glasgow who has a strong independent streak and has developed a serious crush on one of his regular passengers, a woman from Nicaragua named Carla (Oyanka Cabezas). Carla is occasionally short of money for her fare, so George lets her ride for free; when his boss finds out it is added to his list of insubordinations, and George is fired. George keeps in touch with Carla and discovers that she is actually a refugee from Nicaragua suffering emotional problems that stem from the disappearance and probable death of her boyfriend, a Sandinista supporter who is believed to have been kidnapped by US-backed Contra rebels. The largely apolitical George travels with Carla to Nicaragua at a time when the Contra-rebels are about to launch their final, lethal assault on the Sandinista government.

results.title: Carl Milles: Swedish sculptor
results.creator_credit: A B Nordish Filmkopici, Radio Sweden and Doreen Denning
results.brief_description: Carl Milles was perhaps one of Sweden’s most famous sculptors. After a survey of the artist - including some unique scenes of his early works, the film takes us on a tour of the Millesgarden where a number of his works are displayed. Following his death, Millesgarden was donated to the State and is now one of Stockholm’s most frequented museums.

results.title: Caring for the mind
results.creator_credit: Pauline Shaw and Granada Television International
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Facts Are These”.
Details some of the stresses, strains and speed of modern living which have made mental illness a common occurrence. Types of treatment and care of the mentally ill are explained.

results.title: Caring for the future
results.creator_credit: State Electricity Commission of Victoria and Jim Hayes
results.brief_description: As demands for electricity is doubled every ten years, the State Electricity Commission of Victoria must plan at least ten years ahead. The film shows the planning that went into the Loy Yang Power plant, when more than fifty interested bodies were consulted and a great deal of careful testing and experimentation was carried out before the final plan was put into action.

results.title: Caring for our country
results.brief_description: Examines three major environmental problems with regards to land use. These are salinity, soil erosion and tree decline. The video explores the ways in which today’s farmers take responsibility for land degradation and the strategies they use to deal with these problems.

results.title: Caring
results.creator_credit: Peter Montagnon, Alasdair Clayre, Patrick Lui and Nigel Houghton
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Heart of the Dragon”.
This program visits Minus Eighteen Street in northern Harbin (Ha-erh-pin) to examine urban life in China, using the family of a railway policeman as an example. Also looks at institutions for those with whom the community cannot cope. Highlights how life is governed by concepts of honour, moral conduct, courtesy and respectful behaviour which are deep rooted in Chinese society.
